III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206 Staff qualifications; volunteer,
Section contractors on central registry
Description • (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has
ongoing contact with children or parents to be a person
who has the ability, experience, education, and training to
perform the duties assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Agency staff attempted to remove food from youth's mouth to
prevent choking and left mark on his face.
Investigation Foster Care Supportive Visitation worker (FCSV worker) was
interviewed via video conference on July 29, 2025, with
MDHHS worker. She stated she meets with parents to conduct a
1 hour lesson on nurturing parenting and then observes 1 hour of
parenting time and steps in if needed. The program is based on
nurturing parenting skills such as knowing age-appropriate
behaviors, emotional development, recognizing child needs,
appropriate punishment and rewards, etc. She has been working
with Parent since April 10, 2025. Holy Cross has case
management, but she is involved as a contracted service provider.
FCSV worker stated on July 22, 2025, a meeting/parenting time
occurred with Parent. Youth A was served peanut butter and jelly
sandwich on white bread and macaroni and cheese for lunch.
Youth A was observed to take big bites and she and Case Aide
reminded him to take smaller bites and ensure it was chewed
thoroughly. At the end of the visit while putting Youth A in the
vehicle she noticed Youth A’s mouth was full of some of the
peanut butter and jelly sandwich that he had not finished chewing
up and swallowing. She notified Parent who then opened his
mouth and confirmed this. FCSV worker had him open his mouth
and was able to get him to spit out a small amount. She then gave
him sips of water, but Youth A still had a good amount of the
sandwich in his mouth. She stated to Parent and Case Aide she
was concerned they needed to get this out of his mouth or have
him chew and swallow the remaining amount of food since they
were concerned he would choke during the 45 minute car ride
back to the foster home.
Case Aide and Parent opened the trunk of the Holy Cross car and
they sat Youth A down. They were trying to give him sips of a
drink and were rubbing his cheeks to encourage him to finish
chewing the food or have him spit it out. FCSV worker stated from
where she was standing, she wasn’t able to see who was doing
2

what. After approximately 10 minutes, FCSV worker switched with
Case Aide, and she was trying to get Youth A to laugh or stick his
tongue out and a small amount of food came out. She also tried
rubbing his checks. Parent held his face while FCSV worker did a
finger swoop to remove most of the food. There was a small
amount of the sandwich in Youth A’s mouth, but he swallowed
that, and they gave him a drink. FCSV worker stated Youth A
never showed any signs or made an audible noise showing any
discomfort. She never observed anyone being rough or doing
anything that would have caused any mark or bruise on Youth A’s
face. She stated he was squirming a bit but nothing excessive.
The overall concern was the long car ride and the risk of Youth A
choking on the food in his mouth. FCSV worker stated she didn’t
notice any redness or marks on Youth A’s cheeks after the visit.
She stated the entire incident took approximately 20 minutes.
Youth A’s face was not continuously held; the efforts were made
in short intervals.
Case Aide was interviewed via telephone on August 8, 2025.
She stated she was the Case Aide for Youth A but is no longer
employed with Holy Cross. On July 22, 2025, there was a
supervised parenting time with Parent and Youth A as well as
FCSV worker. At the conclusion of the visit, it was noticed Youth A
had a lot of food in his mouth and wouldn’t swallow it. There was
concern he would choke during the long car ride back to foster
placement. Case Aide stated she and Parent sat Youth A on the
truck of the vehicle. Parent was trying to get the food out of his
mouth by massaging his cheeks and giving him sips of water.
Since it was peanut butter and jelly sandwich it was more difficult
to get it out of Youth A’s mouth. Youth A was turning his head and
trying to slide down the car. Case Aide stated she and Parent tried
for about 10 minutes and FCSV worker and Parent also tried for
an additional 10 minutes. She didn’t notice anything that was
aggressive or inappropriate. The intent was so that he wouldn’t
choke. Youth A has a history of pocketing food. The car ride was
from Saginaw to Midland. Alexis didn’t notice any marks or
redness until they arrived in Midland. When she went to get Youth
A out of the car seat, she noticed redness and informed Foster
Parent they had attempted to get food out of his mouth.
Foster Parent (FP) was interviewed via telephone on August
11, 2025. She stated her biggest concern is she has repeatedly
verbally told Parent during the 2 years Youth A has been placed in
her care different techniques to utilize and foods he should and
shouldn’t be given based on his ability to chew and swallow. She
clarified when he was initially placed in her care he was being fed
3

through a GI tube in his stomach. He has participated in feeding
therapy. He is now eating food by mouth and had his GI tube
removed in January 2025. Youth A needs thinner fluid like foods
such as apple sauce and yogurt to assist with his swallowing. It’s
also important that Youth A sits in a highchair so he can focus on
his eating. FP stated she has repeatedly told Parent these things
and is frustrated to know during the incident Youth A was given a
peanut butter and jelly sandwich and was walking around while
eating. If he’s given the appropriate food and the appropriate time
for him to eat, he can eat on his own.
FP stated upon returning from parenting time on July 22, 2025,
Case Aide reported to her there was a mark on Youth A’s cheek.
FP asked what caused the mark and Case Aide reported he had
food stuck in his cheek and they didn’t want him in the car for that
length of time with that amount of food still in his mouth. FP stated
she asked Case Aide what type of food was provided and
indicated the fact it was peanut butter and jelly was probably what
caused it. Case Aide reported she and FCSV worker were taking
turns pushing on his cheek for approximately 20 minutes to get
the food out of his mouth. She was concerned based on the
redness and bruising on Youth A ‘s face she ended up taking him
to Urgent Care. She stated the incident happened on Thursday
and the marks on his face were still visible the following Monday
or Tuesday.
Parent was interviewed via telephone on August 11, 2025.
She stated she had a supervised visit with Youth A. At the end of
the visit it was noticed Youth A had a lot of food in his cheek that
he wasn’t swallowing. She stated he had eaten peanut butter and
jelly and had pocketed it in his cheek. She stated she was
previously advised by Complainant to massage his cheek or give
him sips of a drink to encourage him to swallow. She stated she,
Case Aide and FCSV worker tried those techniques for
approximately 15 minutes. Youth A would slowly swallow some
but still had a large amount of food and Alexis needed to leave to
transport him back to the foster placement timely. Eventually Case
Aide grabbed Youth A’s cheeks and FCSV worker put her finger in
his mouth and was able to get the food out of Youth A’s mouth.
Parent stated she didn’t feel that she, Case Aide or FCSV worker
were rough or aggressive. Youth A never showed any signs of
discomfort. She never noticed any marks on Youth A’s face when
they left the visit. His next visit with Parent was the following
Tuesday and there wasn’t a visible mark at that time.
4

Documents reviewed:
• Foster Care Supportive Visitation & In-Home Parent
Education Weekly Progress Report summary from July 22,
2025, visit. Report summarized the incident of Youth A
obtaining a peanut butter and jelly sandwich and pocketing
in his mouth. The report documents appropriate attempts
by Parent, Case Aide and FCSV worker as described in all
3 interviews.
• Picture of Youth A’s face showing red mark on the left side
of his face. Mark is consistent with the efforts described in
interviews to remove pocketed food. No bruising is visible.
Analysis The agency is found in compliance. Based on completed
interviews and review of Youth A’s MISACWIS case file, Case
Aide, FCSV worker and Parent attempted to remove food Youth A
had pocketed in his mouth and would not swallow prior to a 45-
minute commute back to Foster Parent. It was reported there was
concern Youth A would choke on the food during the car ride. A
red mark was later observed on Youth A’s cheek because of
attempts to remove the food, however it was inadvertent and not
malicious in nature.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
